ELECTION OF SPEAKER


    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker) stood up, and addressing himself to the Clerk of Parliament said: Mr Lopez, I propose,

    That Mr Punchardsheram Coomaraswamy do take the Chair of this Parliament as Speaker.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol) stood up, and addressing himself to the Clerk of Parliament said: Mr Lopez, I beg to support the proposal.

    There being only one proposal, the Clerk then declared Mr Punchardsheram Coomaraswamy to have been elected as Speaker of Parliament.

12.18 p.m.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Prime Minister, Members of the Government and Back-benchers, I am deeply conscious of the great honour that lion. Members have done me in re-electing me as Speaker of the House. In thanking all hon. Members, may I say how happy I am that I have gained the confidence of those hon. Members who were also Members of the last Parliament.

    Since I was elected Speaker in August 1966, I have endeavoured to discharge my functions in accordance with the traditions of this high office. In enforcing Standing Orders my rulings may, on occasion, have appeared to be harsh. In accepting them as they

Column: 6

have, hon. Members appreciate that Standing Orders govern our business. To those Members taking their seats for the first time, I would say the only way not to be overawed by Standing Orders is to be familiar with them. In this regard, I know hon. Members will receive all help from the older Members and from the staff of Parliament. They will always be ready to help you, as indeed I am, for, as Speaker, I am servant of the House. In that spirit, I thank hon. Members again.

12.20 p.m.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, hon. Members join me in extending you our congratulations and our co-operation on your

Column: 7

re-election to the Chair. It is nearly two years since you were first elected to the office. Your experience as Speaker must be unique. In two successive Parliaments you sat over a House without an Opposition. First, the Opposition boycotted the House. Next, they boycotted the general elections. But in spite of the extraordinary circumstances, a legislative chamber without the stimulus of provocative criticism, those of us who were in the last Parliament are confident that under your guidance, this House will keep the parliamentary machine in good shape, and also sustain and cultivate the attitudes of tolerance and calculated deference to opposing views.

    Those of us who are natural optimists, or not long acquainted with the social science of psephology, may believe that the return of all 58 Members from the P.A.P, reflects the unanimity of views amongst people outside. My colleagues and I, who have gone through more harrowing times, cannot afford to be so naive, or so ingenuous.

    In 1963, the pro-Communist groups, under the banner of the Barisan Sosialis collected over 30 per cent of the votes and 13 out of 51 seats. True, their fortunes have declined. This is partly the result of our social and economic policies, partly the result of higher political sophistication amongst the voters. But it is mainly because of their own irrational rigid orthodoxy, their obsequious subservience to directives from outside. They have mechanically chanted ridiculous slogans and asserted incredible untruths - that Malaysia does not exist, that "Malaya" includes Singapore, and that the Republic is a sham.

    Even so, had the Communists decided to contest the elections through the Barisan Sosialis, or other front organisations, like the Communist-led trade unions, or the old boys' associations and the cultural groups, I would not have been surprised if they had collected over 15 per cent of the votes, which would have ensured them some

Column: 8

six to eight seats in this House. If they persist in orthodoxy, and their orders continue to be as unrelated to the realities of the situation in and around Singapore as they have been in the last five years, and more important, if our economic and social policies make the progress they have made over the last five years, then by 1973 their electoral support may further sink down perhaps to below 10 per cent. But I doubt if I can give as cheerful an estimate in the corresponding decline of their cadre strength. One of the subsidiary reasons why their electoral support has declined is that they have withdrawn their trained and experienced cadres from open front activity to conserve their strength for future deployment.

    Sir, of the 58 Members in this House, 26 Members have never known what it is to be in a Parliament with an Opposition. Indeed, 16, having been returned unopposed, have never known the rough and tumble of a contested election. To them, I commend Hansard, the report of proceedings of this House since May 1955, particularly the years 1955, 1956, 1959, 1961 to 1963. In 1955, the Governors stopped presiding over sessions of the Legislative Council. A mainly elected Legislative Assembly of 32 Members of whom 25 were elected was allowed to meet under an independent Speaker. Three Members were from the P.A.P. I am the sole survivor of that first Assembly.

    Some of the clerks of Parliament and I have personal knowledge of the boisterous and rumbustious past of this House. There was no dearth or differences of opinions, or independence of views, sometimes sincerely, and often vehemently, held. Hansard records the clash of minds, the exchange of retorts courteous and not so courteous, the conflict of ideas and ideologies, and the face-to-face confrontation of the exponents of different ideologies.

    They reveal all the bounce, the abrasiveness and the self-confidence that Singapore had and still has. They made for lively meetings. Debates were often bitter and vicious. The fact that we now

Column: 9

have such a homogeneous group in 58 Members does not mean that it will remain so hereafter. Opposition in this Chamber will and must inevitably return. But the Opposition will not be individuals claiming to act as the conscience of the people, or offering themselves as the necessary accoutrements of parliamentary democracy on the spurious argument that, because there is no Opposition, therefore there is no parliamentary democracy. Singapore is not that gullible and credulous.

    The Opposition, when it returns, will comprise a group offering an alternative policy, and offering themselves as a credible alternative government to implement the policies they expound. This could come about in one of two ways, one less desirable than the other. First, it could come as a result of severe economic setbacks, the failure to meet and overcome the problems coming upon us in the l970s. Then the Opposition that emerges will be extreme, either orthodox Communist or revisionist, or Trotskyite. Then divisions will be sharp and angry, and the country the worse for it.

    Second, the more desirable alternative, economic success and enhanced social stability, and further reduction in electoral support for Communist or extremist policies. With stability and prosperity, the sense of national urgency and unity which binds together a people faced with common danger, will slacken and a more relaxed mood will set in. A new restlessness will bestir the people, a desire for improvement and change, or just change for change's sake, will appeal to a younger generation. The emergence of a party or parties either to the left or right of the P.A.P, must result. But they would be constitutional alternatives, willing to work the system, prepared to compete and attain power within the system, and to surrender it by the same rules through which they came into office.

    But for the crucial 1970s, it is as well that in the P.A.P, we hold together in national consensus a wide cross-section of our society, from semi-skilled and

Column: 10

skilled workers like the Members for Kampong Kembangan and Geylang Serai, both former employees of the Singapore Telephone Board and leaders of its union, clerical groups represented by the Members for Kallang and Toa Payoh, teachers and principals like the Members for Telok Blangah and Moulmein, university lecturers and professors like the Members for Katong, Joo Chiat and Alexandra, to professional men and business executives like the Members for Bukit Panjang, River Valley and Jalan Kayu. Our task, Mr Speaker, is to help you ensure that the parliamentary machine is well-maintained and tuned to meet the new circumstances that will evolve in the 1970s.

    I am confident that hon. Members will debate matters before them frankly and freely. More than half of hon. Members, however, have never taken part in a debate with an Opposition like that we had from 1961 to 1963. Then attack was not only venomous and sharp, but ruthless and unprincipled, and criticism was intended not to point out defects and secure improvements but designed electorally to kill and destroy the other side by fair means or foul. Hon. Members will have to learn and practise, as much outside as inside Parliament, the cut and thrust of debate, the retort and rejoinder, the rebuttal and riposte. I am told that simulated flying in a cockpit is nearly the same thing as actually flying an aircraft, except for the eerie feeling a pilot gets when he finds himself aloft and alone.

    For more than four years from 1955 to 1959, I was a Member of this Chamber occupying the seat, if not the title, of Leader of the Opposition. At every crisis, crowds thronged the Gallery to watch the Government being castigated and whipped for its many misdemeanours. I changed places and became Leader of the Government from 1959 onwards. It was our turn to be pulverised. From 1961 to 1963 crowds were drawn like a magnet to this Chamber, some waiting outside to hear, if they could not see, the pack of Barisan wolves come in for the kill of the

Column: 11

P.A.P. lamb. I do not believe that these large numbers of pro-Communist sympathisers and supporters have all vanished or been converted just because they left disappointed, as the Barisan wolves were chastised in the encounter.

    Finally, Mr Speaker, Sir, whilst this will not be a Parliament with the suspense and excitement of its earlier years, nevertheless, there will be momentous times ahead for all of us, and this House will have enough drama if not anxiety in the crucial years ahead. Hon. Members will speak their minds freely and forcefully. Our future is at stake and we must give the lead in thinking and feeling in the country. If the new Members we now welcome to our fraternity learn and drill themselves, there is no reason why, when actual blood is drawn in a subsequent Parliament, that it should not be from the other side.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, may you preside over us to a more secure and triumphant Third Parliament.

    Mr Speaker: I thank you, Mr Prime Minister.

    I have to report to the House that the President will be in this House at 7 o'clock this evening to address Parliament. The business set down for this morning being concluded, I now suspend the House until 7 p.m.

Sitting accordingly suspended at
12.35 p.m. until 7 p.m.


Column: 11

Column: 12



7.04 p.m.
PRESIDENT'S SPEECH


    The President (Inche Yusof bin Ishak)(In Malay): Honourable Members, we are met today after a general election in which 51 Honourable Members were returned unopposed and the rest, seven from the same party, returned with clear majorities. This is a Parliament which is faced with problems of more than usual magnitude. It is not only because Britain will be withdrawing her forces by the end of 1971. The whole security and political situation in South and Southeast Asia is in the process of change. The balance of forces, which have more or less held the position since 1954 when the French relinquished power over the whole of Vietnam, and the Americans stepped into the breach in the south, is now poised for a possible major shift.

    Momentous changes in the political and security pattern of the region have already been set in motion. By the end of the term of this Parliament in 1973, it is probable that new security and political patterns would have begun to emerge. Peace and security will have to be ensured under different circumstances.

    These historic events will have a profound influence on our future. Perhaps it was the awareness of this that made Singapore vote almost unanimously for the P.A.P. In the next five to ten years, issues of life and death will be determined more by factors around, rather than within, Singapore.

    (In English): My Government will seek to achieve three objectives:

    First, optimum use of the time available to build up an effective defence capability which, in conjunction with Malaysia and our other Commonwealth partners, can ensure continuing security. This must be done at minimum cost, so that most of our resources will go into economic development. It means that, although we have small numbers on active service, we shall have large numbers in the reserve service. These

Column: 13

reserves will be well and regularly trained, ready for combat, but otherwise they will be in productive employment, contributing to the economic growth and progress of the country.

    Second, greater economic growth, higher productivity with the elimination of restrictive practices, abuses of fringe benefits, and more efficient management. With ever lower costs we must reach out for more export markets. The continuance and consolidation of stable political and social conditions, sensible relations between labour, management and government, these are the pre-conditions for increased investments in the industrial and servicing sectors to create meaningful jobs for ever-increasing numbers of our more educated citizens seeking better jobs.

    Third, enhancement of national consciousness of the problems that will come upon us in the next few years. We must all learn to place national interests above personal or sectional interests. Internally, high morale - internationally, confidence in our continuing stability and efficiency - this combination will enable us to achieve new records in high performance.

    The broad outlines of policy for each Ministry in my Government are set out in an addendum* to this Address. To sum them up, it is to get full value for every dollar spent. To do this, everyone must put in a full day's work for a full
* Cols. 15-32.


Column: 14

day's wage. Sacrifice and greater effort in an emergency comes naturally to those who seek group, as against individual, salvation.

    The resilience, resourcefulness and the indomitable spirit we have demonstrated in the last decade, they will enable us to overcome the problems following in the wake of changes in the security and economic conditions of the region we live in. These problems appear daunting only to the faint hearted.

    Finally, I would wish Honourable Members to speak in forthright terms to reflect and more important to lead thinking and feeling in the country, to ensure that everyone understands the challenge and gives of his best.

    I wish Honourable Members a rewarding five years. May your deliberations and decisions leave the Republic the more flourishing and secure at the end of your term.

7.14 p.m.

    At the conclusion of the President's speech, Mr Speaker, preceded by the Serjeant at Arms, the Clerk, the Clerk-Assistant and the Second Clerk-Assistant, escorted the President (accompanied by two A.D.C.s) out of the Chamber, and the House adjourned without question put, pursuant to the Standing Order.

Adjourned accordingly
at 7.14 p.m.


Column: 15

MEMORANDUM PRESENTED TO PARLIAMENT AS AN ADDENDUM
TO THE ADDRESS BY THE PRESIDENT


    Outlines of policy on matters of finance, defence, foreign affairs, industrial and technical training and technological education, have already been set out in speeches by respective Ministers.

MINISTRY OF LABOUR


Comprehensive Labour Legislation

    A comprehensive Employment Bill will be introduced in Parliament. The Bill will standardize and regulate the terms and conditions of employment for all employees irrespective of whether they are workmen, clerks or shop assistants and the existing Labour Ordinance, 1955, the Shop Assistants Employment Ordinance, 1957, and the Clerks Employment Ordinance, 1957, will be repealed. Among other things the Bill will provide a standard working week of 44 hours for all employees, regulate overtime work, to enable a wider spread of employment, limit certain fringe benefits to lessen abuses and increase productivity and promote more industrial growth.

Central Provident Fund

    It is necessary to mobilise domestic savings to be employed in our counter recession strategy. Under consideration are selected increases in the rates of Central Provident Fund contributions and a new range of contributors covering all employees including those in Government and Statutory Boards in addition to their pensions or other provident fund benefits and self employed persons.

    Concurrently a scheme is being worked out between the Ministry and the Housing and Development Board to enable balances in the present Central Provident Fund to be set off against the first instalment of Housing Board flats. The additional Central Provident Fund contributions can be used to pay off monthly instalments of both Housing

Column: 16

and Development Board and privately built homes. It is estimated that about 60 per cent of the 2, 3 and 4-room tenants of the Housing and Development Board flats will thus be enabled to purchase their present flats. The lowering of assessments is also being considered to make the home ownership scheme attractive.

Training

    The Hotel and Catering Training Centre will be extended to train waiters, barmen, room stewards, receptionists and cashiers for the expanding hotel and catering industry. Technical assistance had been sought under the Colombo Plan and the I.L.O. for the expansion of the Training Centre. Soon the training of cooks and courses for supervisory and management personnel will also be conducted at the Centre.

    A crash programme for the retraining of redundant base workers was started in April this year at the Singapore Vocational Institute, the Economic Development Board's Workshop, Polytechnic and at 5 secondary technical schools. These training courses will equip retrenched workers with the basic skills in various trades. Further, steps have been taken to establish industrial training centres which will be equipped with modern machinery to enable trainees to gain actual production experience. These centres will offer training and retraining facilities not only to our citizens retrenched by the British Services but also to school-leavers who desire to acquire industrial skills to get employment in blue collar jobs.

Manpower Planning

    A Manpower Planning Committee will be established to study the supply and demand position in depth and breadth. The studies will embrace educational and training requirements and supply the necessary information for comprehensive manpower planning.

Column: 17

MINISTRY OF EDUCATION


    In education, the available resources of the Government will be directed mainly towards the following targets: -

    (a) A reorganisation of the secondary school system to divert a much larger number of students to technical education and vocational training. A Cabinet Committee with the Minister for Education as Chairman, Minister for Science and Technology, Minister for Labour and Minister for Finance has been set up to supervise the planning and co-ordination of technical and vocational training on a national basis with the object of avoiding duplication of effort and ensuring that technical education and vocational training will be keyed to manpower needs and employment opportunities.

    (b) A concerted effort to produce effectively bilingual school -leavers to ensure wider opportunities for higher education and employment in our multi-racial society. Increasing use will be made of the second language as a medium of instruction. As far as possible, students in non-English language schools will study mathematics, science and technology in the medium of English and the humanities through one of the other, either their mother language Malay, Chinese or Tamil. In English language schools, the mother tongue will be more extensively used to make students effectively literate and fluent in a second language.

    (c) Increasing emphasis on quality at all levels of education to make up for shortcomings in the past necessitated by the

Column: 18

unprecedented rate of expansion in the school system to provide a place for every child. Now that this quantitative target has been achieved, attention will be turned to qualitative improvement in such fields as curriculum reform, textbooks and teaching aids, teaching techniques, teacher training and re-training, examinations, health education, physical education, art and music, and all forms of extramural activity. A few well-established secondary schools will be converted to single-session schools, so that maximum use may be made by students of laboratories, school libraries, playing fields and other amenities.

    (d) Integration of the 4 language streams is to be extended to aided schools wherever possible. The policy of integration, which has helped to overcome the language barrier, has so far been confined to Government schools only. Ways and means will be found to introduce the system to aided schools.

Column: 18

MINISTRY OF COMMUNICATIONS


    The geographic and strategic importance of Singapore gives us an edge in the field of transportation and communications.

Marine

    Last year, a record number of 28,496 vessels or 117.3 million net registered tons of shipping used our port facilities. Singapore became the No. 1 port in the Commonwealth and moved from 5th to 4th port in the world.

    Proper terminal facilities for ocean-going container vessels at the East Lagoon have been under construction at a total cost of over $77 million. They will be operational by 1970.

Column: 19



    The efficiency and productivity of our port, both workers and management, must be demonstrated in quicker turn-round of ships.

    There has been considerable progress in shipbuilding and ship repairing business at the Port of Singapore Authority Dockyard, at Jurong, Kallang and Tanjong Rhu shipyards. This is a highly labour intensive industry. The naval base at Sembawang will be converted into a commercial dockyard, even whilst the Royal Navy is using the Base. This conversion work may commence this year.

Telecommunications

    Singapore has long been a major regional and world centre for telecommunications. To keep abreast of satellite communications, we have decided to install an Earth Satellite Station in Singapore to be operational by 1970. This station will be supplementary to the Seacom cable system. It will enable Singapore to obtain direct link via the Indian Ocean Satellite with other similarly equipped countries from Japan and America in the East to Britain and Europe in the West.

    In addition to normal telecommunication facilities, the Earth Satellite Station can provide a means for the reception and transmission of television programmes, thus enabling Singapore viewers to link up with the main centres of civilisation the world over.

    The Singapore Telephone Board has over 108,000 telephones and 76,000 direct lines are in service. 98 per cent of subscribers are now connected to the automatic Subscriber Trunk Dialling Service (STD). The Singapore Telephone Board will have not only to expand its services to keep pace with the increasing demand for its services but also to improve its standards of maintenance and efficiency.

Aviation

    1967 was a record year with 964,244 passengers (25 per cent increase over the previous year) 8.6 million kilos of air cargo (11 per cent increase) and 1.8

Column: 20

million kilos of mail (26 per cent increase) being handled by our airport authorities.

    Twenty-one international airlines run scheduled services through Singapore and work is in progress for the extension of the runway from 9,000 feet to 11,000 feet to get Singapore Airport to receive the jumbo jets.

    Modern equipment such as Visual Approach Slope Indicators, Instrument Landing System and an Airport Location Beacon have been or are being installed to maintain high standards of safety and efficient operation. An aircraft engineering facilities building is nearing completion.

Postal Services

    A record 192 million articles of mail were handled by our Postal Services during 1967. We must maintain high standards of efficiency under even heavy loads of mail traffic.

    The following agency services were continued during the year, namely: -

    (a) collection and payment of Central Provident Fund contributions,

    (b) payment of Social Welfare Public Assistance allowances,

    (c) payment of civil pensions and allowances for Army and Air Force personnel.

Legislation is being drawn up to permit renewal of driving licences at post offices, on behalf of the Registrar of Vehicles.

    Five new Post Offices (2 of which will be replacement offices) will be built by 1969, thus bringing the total number of Post Offices to 44.

Road Transport

    The offices of the Registrar of Vehicles at Middle Road will be reorganised in order to streamline work procedures and to ease congestion for large numbers of licence holders who regularly pay their dues at this office.

Column: 21



    A new driving licence testing centre is being built in Queenstown expected to be completed by November this year. This should relieve the present congestion at Maxwell Road centre.

    To help reduce traffic congestion, the services of 2 officials from the London Transport Board have been obtained under the Colombo Plan Technical Co-operation Scheme to advise on possible solutions to our growing passenger transport problem.

    There will be an intensification of the campaign to stamp out the smoke nuisance (air pollution) from motor vehicles and to improve Road-Safety consciousness amongst road users to reduce unnecessary heavy casualties on the roads.

Column: 21

MINISTRY OF CULTURE


    To get our people better prepared and to participate more in the immense national effort required in the crucial years ahead, the mass media of Radio, Television and publications will be improved and expanded. The Library, the Museum, the Printing Office together with Radio and Television will not only inform, entertain and educate but will also stimulate patriotism, public-spiritedness and the importance of increased productivity. An appreciation for dancing, music, art and other cultural and artistic activities will be assiduously encouraged especially amongst the young.

    The Museum which will now come under the Ministry of Science and Technology will be modernised to serve as an educational centre displaying in vivid manner the rich political, social and economic history not only of Singapore but of the whole region of which we are the fulcrum.

    Our Library facilities will be expanded. Work on a branch library will start later in the year. Mobile library services will reach more people.

    The magnitude of the tasks ahead, and the need to carry the people with us in the new policies to meet these

Column: 22

tasks increases the need for good mass communication media. Television and Radio will be elevated into a separate Division within the Ministry of Culture under a separate Permanent Secretary.

Column: 22

MINISTRY OF SOCIAL AFFAIRS


    The increase in Defence expenditure in the coming years will necessarily limit expansion of Social Welfare services. To make the best available use of the vote on Social Welfare services, the 12 institutions operated by the Social Welfare Department will be encouraged to provide their own domestic services instead of depending on paid staff. Residents of Homes will also be trained to undertake work, the proceeds of which will assist in paying for the running of the Homes. Examination will be undertaken to see that the services provided in the Social Welfare Department's Children Centres and Creches are not duplicated by similar services provided by other organisations and voluntary welfare bodies. Voluntary welfare organisations will be encouraged in their work to provide services to the handicapped, the disabled and the aged in our community. Steps have already been taken to increase the number of voluntary helpers in these voluntary institutions and in the Social Welfare Department Homes. It is encouraging to note that more of our women are coming forward to undertake voluntary welfare work in the way as our young men are undertaking National Service.

    Greater emphasis will be given to sports. A Sports Division has been created, to promote and encourage sports in Singapore. The National Sports Stadium at Kallang, piling work for which is still being carried out at present, is expected to be completed by the end of 1970. This will be the centre for the training of all our students from all schools and universities who show promise. Coaches will be employed for the various games and sports to raise the standards of performance in athletics, swimming and games.

Column: 23

MINISTRY OF LAW


Public Utilities

    The growth of the Public Utilities Board's operations in recent years has been unprecedented.

    Electrical sales have risen at an annual rate of 15 per cent. Of this, the demands from industries have increased at a phenomenal rate of 23 per cent. To meet this, the Public Utilities Board having completed the construction of the Pasir Panjang `B' Power Station in 1966, has now begun construction of the Jurong Power Station. The first two units will be completed in 1969 at a total cost of $82 million.

    The Johore River Waterworks was commissioned in July 1967. Work has commenced on the Seletar Project, which will be completed in 1970. Several other projects to increase yield and storage in Singapore are under way.

    An indication of the rapid expansion is that $63 million was in 1967 for capital development, whilst $140 million is budgeted for 1968.

Column: 23

MINISTRY OF NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT


Housing

    The target of the Second Five Year Housing Programme (1966-70) of the Housing and Development Board has been the building of 12,000 flats a year. This target has been more than achieved. However, in view of the continued demand for more public housing, both for rental and for sale to citizens, under the "Home Ownership Scheme", the Board plans to build up to 16,500 units per year for the remaining period of the Second Five Year Plan.

    The Board at present manages some 100,000 housing units accommodating a quarter of our total population.

    The biggest project now under development is Toa Payoh New Town. Approximately 8,000 units have already been completed. A further 7,000 units are under construction. Extensive sites have been cleared and the piling for more buildings is in progress. When this

Column: 24

new town is completed in 1970 - 71, it will provide modern homes for more than 200,000 people with all the modern amenities for comfortable living.

    More and more Housing Board flats will be offered for sale. The Government and the Housing and Development Board are working out new ways and means to enable as many sitting tenants as possible to buy their own homes.

    The Housing Board has so far built 3 blocks of flatted factories - 2 blocks in Kallang Basin and one in Tiong Bahru. In consultation with the Economic Development Board, more flatted factories will be built in the next four years to accommodate labour intensive industries in or adjacent to housing estates. The demand for this type of flatted factories has been steadily growing because of its advantageous position next to large and convenient sources of labour from the housing estates in the neighbourhood.

Land Reclamation

    The Republic's major land reclamation scheme along the East Coast is progressing satisfactorily. When completed in 1970 more than 1,000 acres of coastal land stretching from Bedok to Tanjong Rhu for about 6 miles will he added. Apart from the major coastal highway that has to be constructed, plans are now being examined to ensure the optimum usage of this land.

    The other reclamation scheme at the Kallang Basin which entails the filling of the tidal swamp with earth from Toa Payoh will be completed in 1969. This will yield some 380 acres of land for industrial and housing development.

    Work on one other reclamation scheme at Pasir Panjang adjacent to the Haw Par Villa is commencing. Several other schemes at Woodlands, Nicoll Highway, Bedok to Tanah Merah Besar are under detailed investigations.

Urban Renewal and Redevelopment

    The entire Central Area of the City of about 1,700 acres has been divided into 17 precincts, grouped mainly in 2 localities in relation to the position

Column: 25

North and South of the Singapore River. The plan is to redevelop the older parts of this whole Central Area systematically in stages over a period of years. Under the Second Five-Year Development Plan, an estimated total of $125 million will be spent on the development of the initial 2 precincts, referred to as N.l (Crawford) and S.1 (Outram). Work in these 2 precincts began in 1966 and is progressing smoothly. In Precinct N.l, 3 blocks of multi-storey flats and shops at Palembang Road have been completed and when occupied will transform the skyline of this once dilapidated area into a modern high rise centre. In Precinct 5.1, on the site of the old Outram Prison, 8 blocks of multi-storey flats and shops and another 4 blocks of lock-up shops are nearing completion.

    However, the complete success of urban renewal includes substantial participation by the private sector in high quality buildings. To encourage and promote this, administrative changes and incentive measures have been introduced. For example, approved projects such as hotels, office buildings and luxury apartments in designated areas, will have property tax reduced to 12 per cent per annum for 20 years. In addition, a legislation will be re-introduced to enable genuine developers to recover their rent-controlled properties in designated areas for redevelopment. Tenants of these affected premises will be compensated fairly, and will be given adequate time to move to alternative accommodation which includes Housing and Development Board premises.

    The sale of State lands by public tender of 14 strategic sites suitable for a wide range of projects from hotels, entertainment centres, floating restaurants to office buildings and shopping centres on attractive terms has resulted in 7 out of the 14 sites offered being sold. In addition, negotiations have now reached a stage where 3 more sites along the "Golden Mile" may soon be taken up for hotel development. Plans are now being made to release more State lands for private development to

Column: 26

meet a wide range of high quality development.

Physical Planning and Building Control

    The State and City Planning Project assisted by the United Nations Development Programme (Special Fund) has been launched and will operate for 4 years to produce comprehensive long-range land use and transportation plans which will provide proper guidance, and greater flexibility in the control and use of our scarce land resources. Whilst the long-range concept plans are being formulated by the technically skilled experts associated with the Project, the day-to-day control of land use and development is still subject to the Master Plan. The Planning Department and the Development Control Division of the Chief Building Surveyor's Department will ensure that plans for development are approved more expeditiously.

    Administrative reforms to streamline control procedures will enable planning applications to be processed with the minimum of delay. Planners will review and relax wherever possible plot ratio and density controls so that our limited land area can be more intensively utilised, provided other planning criteria are satisfied, and developers are prepared to pay the requisite development charge.

Public Works

    The traditional role of the Public Works Department as a Government agency for the maintenance of public buildings and the construction of bridges, roads, schools, clinics, etc, has to be widened to assume a more active role in providing suitable basic infrastructure for increased economic development. During the next 4 years the Public Works Department will execute an expanded programme of public works which will entail an additional expenditure of $250 million for 1968 - 70 over and above the current provision in the Second Five-Year Plan.

    Singapore's major flood alleviation scheme at Bukit Timah after years of preparation was finally launched in 1967.

Column: 27

When completed it will relieve the flooding in the Bukit Timah area by diverting waters into Sungei Ulu Pandan.

    The increasing needs of the new housing estates and industries demand that the sewerage system be extended to cover an even more extensive area. Recent sewerage projects include Toa Payoh, Jurong, Kallang Basin and urban renewal areas.

    Traffic problems continue to tax the wits of our transport and traffic planners and engineers. Short term measures include improvements made to existing road junctions and one-way traffic systems to facilitate smoother flow of traffic. As an intermediate term measure the Department is undertaking the construction of a number of flyovers and grade separated interchanges at major road junctions to ensure the smoother flow of heavy traffic. Main arterial roads have also been widened to provide for dual carriageways wherever it is possible to acquire land to do so. Long-term measures will continue to be studied, investigated and worked out in conjunction with the State and City Planning Project in order to lay down a comprehensive but flexible traffic plan for the future.

    Two major road programmes to be implemented soon are: -

    (1) the plan to construct a coastal highway along the East Coast reclaimed land linking traffic from the eastern sector of the Island to the City; and

    (2) the plan for a Pan-Island Ex pressway connecting the Jurong Industrial Estate, the proposed Woodlands New Town, the Toa Payoh New Town and the Kallang Basin.

Parts of the Pan-Island Expressway are under construction and external loan will be sought to finance these two major highway projects.

    Plans to make Singapore a Garden City, the cleanest and greenest in South-east Asia are being implemented assiduously. A Parks and Trees Division has

Column: 28

been established within the Public Works Department. Improvement to the Botanic Gardens, the Van Kleef Aquarium and many of the Public Parks will be made. Some 15,000 trees of 50 varieties have been planted since June, 1967. Other projects to beautify our highways and other public thoroughfares, road circuses, open spaces, schools arid other public institutions are being pursued. The private sector will be encouraged to make a corresponding effort.

Primary Production and Urban and Rural Services

    The provision of services and advice to our farmers enable them to increase their farm products and reduce production costs. Increasing productivity and reducing costs of production in the agricultural sector is a constant objective. Particular emphasis is on the promotion of intensive and diversified farming to make maximum use of our limited land resources.

    As for the Fisheries Industry, the emphasis is on off-shore and deep-sea fishing. Considerable efforts are being made towards improving the system of fish landing, marketing and distribution as well as in the training of a new generation of fishermen for off-shore and deep-sea fishing. The construction of the Fisheries Wharf and Central Fish Auction Market at Jurong is a step in this direction as also is the establishment of the Fishing Training Institute with the assistance of the United Nations Development Programme at Changi.

    The Jurong Abattoir, completed at a cost of about $6 million will ensure that the slaughter of sheep, cattle and pigs, meat handling and inspection will be run on modern assembly line system to achieve high hygienic standards. The export market for canned meat will be exploited.

    The breeding of tropical and fancy fish as an industry to earn more foreign exchange is being encouraged and assisted. This industry can be carried out in any home as a part-time job for earning extra money. Horticulture, particularly the growing of orchids, for

Column: 29

which our climatic conditions are ideal, will be assisted by research and new free flowering hybrids to take greater advantage of the export market.

    The Urban and Rural Services Committee will continue to facilitate the supply of electricity and water in the rural areas and to provide better communication and drainage. As part of a special campaign water supplies are being laid direct to home in order that public standpipes can be removed.

Column: 29

MINISTRY OF HEALTH


    Now that full establishment has been reached for all grades of staff, the time has come to chart the future progress by striking out on a new course.

    The task in the coming years will be to sustain the high standards already achieved. The key-note will be greater sophistication in the Health Services together with greater demands on the civic responsibility particularly in public health measures. It is essential that in the reappraisal of development, priorities are assigned; costs are kept down as far as possible without stunting growth.

Environmental Health

    The new sophistication will be apparent in the new and aggressive approach to the challenge of keeping Singapore clean. A "people orientated problem" being more complex will require that the main effort will be directed in wrestling out a successful solution which will involve mass participation of the public.

    Progress has been made in recent years in the control of hawkers by licensing and re-siting. The labour force of the Cleansing Services will have to be further reorganised for better efficiency and discipline. There is much room for improvement. Dirt, flies and mosquitoes are all too evident. The recent occurrence of two cases of cholera underscores the need for maintaining vigilance and the highest standards of sanitation.

    The Public Health Division will be strengthened by integrating some of its sections which have hitherto been

Column: 30

working as separate units; by strengthening the supervisory staff to achieve better control and discipline. Reappraisal or the methods of collection, haulage and disposal of rubbish to improve the efficiency of procedures.

    At the same time the people will have to play their part as citizens in making Singapore a garden city. For those who are incorrigible, new laws will be enacted to penalise litter bugs, and those who unnecessarily add to the c1eansing problem.

    Public Health legislation is being consolidated into a comprehensive environmental health code capable of maintaining the highest standards of public health required in a modern complex urban society.

Hospitals

    The aim is to develop the medical care services as a premier curative service. Further hospital accommodation will have to be manned when the British Services vacate their hospitals at Alexandra, the British Military Hospital - 400 beds; at Changi - 125 beds; at Sembawang - 74 beds.

    The development of certain sophisticated specialties will be selected for stimulated development to standards equal to the best in the world. We must keep abreast with the latest in the world and keep up facilities, knowledge and skills as the best and highest in the region. The construction of the Institute of Medical Specialties as a joint project with the University has already started. The first section to house the Cobalt Units will be completed about August of this year. The other sections for the specialties such as the artificial kidney unit; cardiac unit, open-heart surgery, neurology, neuro-surgery, gastrology and others will be built soon. Some of these units have already been established within existing facilities in the hospitals e.g, an artificial kidney unit in the Outram General Hospital; a neuro-surgical unit in the Thomson General Hospital and a Cardiac-vascular Surgical Unit in the Tan Tock Seng Hospital.

Column: 31



Dental Health

    Dental health services require to be improved and expanded. The standards of dental care amongst the population are low. Only the younger generation of the population show the beneficial effects of fluoridation of the water supplies which started in 1958. Although the main effort for dental care is directed at school children (there are 50 school dental clinics) it reaches less than half the primary school-going population.

    Improvement in dental health will be achieved if there is greater attention to dental hygiene and if dental services become more universally available. Great stress will therefore be placed on an intensive and sustained dental health education programme. This will be started in the schools and then directed to the general public. Dissemination of dental health knowledge is regarded as urgent at this stage as our population is not conscious enough of the importance of maintaining dental health.

    The dental care services will be expanded as rapidly as resources are available. The limitation is the shortage of dentists (there being only 156 Division I registered dentists in Singapore; 60 of whom are in Government service). Priority will be given to the establishment of dental clinics for school children.

Medical Charges

    The maintenance of the Health Service and its plans for development make an ever growing demand on the public purse. Already 12 per cent of the Republic's budget (or $78,000,000) is apportioned to the Health Service. The rise in costs cannot be sustained without limit without either contracting the services or a fall in the standards of health practices.

    Neither alternative is acceptable. Hence some other means of holding down costs is essential.

Column: 32



    Since the services are almost entirely free a token proportion of the costs will have to be borne by patients if the services are not to be limited.

    A revision on medical fees is therefore being undertaken on the principle that services must be partially paid for. Examples of the proposed revision will be: -

    (a) extending charges for hospital care to classes of patients who have hitherto been treated and fed free;

    (b) increasing the number of paying class beds in hospitals (there are insufficient B class beds to meet the increasing demands chiefly due to the increasing number of collective agreements where employees, are entitled to admission to paying class wards);

    (c) charges for workmen injured at work and persons injured in road traffic accidents who are covered by Workmen's Compensation or third-party insurance schemes, respectively;

    (d) increasing outpatient charges per attendance and for attendances during Sundays and public holidays;

    (e) enhanced accouchement charges for the third and further child to discourage families who can least afford to increase their numbers.

Family Planning

    If the economic growth, social development and the quality of living is to be maintained and not absorbed by over-population the family planning programme will have to be pursued to maintain the accelerated drop in birthrates. Family planning, which has achieved notable results in recent years, will be prosecuted with greater vigour augmented by the proposed legislation to legalise abortions and the voluntary sterilization of persons.
